powerHeader.commentMode.markdownDescription:
ğŸ’¬ How to comment header text assembled from **Template**.  

Attention âš ï¸  

Not all languages support all modes; e.g.  

- *js* has both (`// /* */`)  

- *html* or *css* only block tags (`<!-- -->` / `/* */`)  

- *shell* however only line tag (`REM`, `#`)  

You can use language specific overwrites in *settings.json*: `"[shellscript]": { "powerHeader.commentMode": "line" }` in these cases.

powerHeader.template.markdownDescription:
ğŸ“„ Header template text or URI.  

See **Variables** for string interpolation options.  

Template examples:  

- Plain text `Author: <author>\n(c) $CURRENT_YEAR`  

- File containing template text in current workspace `file://$WORKSPACE_FOLDER/template.txt`  

- Local file `file://C:/windows/header.txt`  

- Local file `file:///opt/linux/header`  

- Remote `https://raw.githubusercontent.com/microsoft/vscode/snippet/snippetVariables.ts`  

â˜ï¸ To initiate URI interpolation at least one variable must contain a `$`-[sigil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sigil_(computer_programming)).

powerHeader.variables.markdownDescription:
ğŸ”€ Variables for interpolation in **Template** and **Content**.  

You can use all [vscode snippet variables](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/userdefinedsnippets#_variables) and define custom variable pairs here in [INI file format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INI_file#Format) `name=value`.  

`value` is evaluated as JavaScript code before  replace(`name`), allowing for arbitrary complex text â€” use 'quotes' for string values!  

â˜ï¸ Interpolation is done in the order of this list (lastly vscode snippet variables); e.g. `a='b'` followed by `b='c'` would be equal to `a='c'` â€” keep an eye out on not accidentally overwriting names from values or use this to your advantage.
